content.description: A diagonally directed climb with a bulge that offers few features to surmount. Crux is at the 5th bolt to get over the bulge. One may choose to go right at the 5th bolt and use a good ledge to crimps and side pulls to gain better features. Alternatively you can go left at the 5th bolt (careful of a potential swing on lead!) on easier terrain but a delicate traverse sequence but you can find decent hands and feet so you can clip the last bolt.
content.location: Shares same first bolt as unknown route 5 and follow the obvious right trending bolt line to the small bulge.

content.description:
Route starts with a ~3" crack in a corner that you can either lie-back or climb with a combination of jams and face moves, protects well. Crack tapers to face and finger cracks Â with thin feet. Pro is more sparse for the second half of the route and beware of loose holds. A few seemingly obvious holds jiggle, but there are many less obvious holds and solid crack holds.

The 5.10a rating is based on rumors that it was originally graded 5.10a. The bottom half is easier (around, 5.8), while the top half requires a few moves in the 5.10 range, but is mostly 5.9.
content.protection: Standard trad rack. BD #3 (blue) protects the wide crack at the bottom, while thinner gear (BD #0.4 and smaller) is best for the top. Bolts with rap-rings are located above the route, to the right of the small roof at the top of the route.
content.location: From the turnout for the Lower Power Station climbing area, walk south along Hwy 178, stay behind the big boulders that provide protection from the highway. After ~50 feet, you will see a rough trail that trends up the hill towards the rock face. The climb should be a 50 foot scramble up the gritty trail. You can belay from 15 below the start of the climb where there are better stances and a few flat surfaces.

content.description: Jug haul with some smearing but always within reach of a positive hold. Be cautious of the rock up top. Make sure to always check the rock as a lot of hollow blocks up top.
On the longer wall follow the most left crack with good jams. Crux comes traversing to the right to clip the 3 bolt adjoining the route to the right.
content.location: Far most left crack on the taller wall.

content.description: Follow the crack straight up to gain the ledge and join the other two routes on the left.
Start on a wide crack gaining some height to the cruxy slab section. Surmount it to a large ledge to one more bolt and to the anchors.
content.location: Far left bolted route when facing towards the power station.

content.description: Good jamming with great features within the cracks and on the face. The crux comes after the fifth bolt with a difficult sequencing within the crack for a horn.
content.protection: Standard rack for the trad lead otherwise several quick draws for the sport lead.
content.location: On the right of the cliff above a steep trail to a bolted belay station with an old rope to secure the belayer.

content.description: Far right most bolt line when facing the tall wall. Easy terrain leads to somewhat difficult lieback moves. The lieback is the most straightforward way to get up the final section of the climb.
content.location: Far most right bolt line on the tall wall before the wall levels out.
